questions.text: A 2-day-old term neonate was found to have blotchy erythematous papules on chest, with a few yellow-white lesions on day 2 of life, as shown in the image. Palms and soles were spared. There were no other significant complaints. Eosinophils were found in the intralesional smears stained with Wright's stain. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Erythema Toxicum

  • A benign, self-limited, evanescent eruption, erythema toxicum occurs in approximately 50% of full-term infants; preterm infants are affected less commonly.
  • The lesions are firm, erythematous or yellow-white, 1-2 mm papules or pustules with a surrounding erythematous flare. At times, splotchy erythema is the only manifestation.
  • The palms and soles are usually spared.
  • Peak incidence occurs on the 2nd day of life, but new lesions may erupt during the first few days as the rash waxes and wanes.
  • Eosinophils can be demonstrated in Wright-stained smears of the intralesional contents. Cultures are sterile.
  • Resolves in 3-7 days without any therapy.
  • Slate-blue, well-demarcated areas of pigmentation called Mongolian spots are seen over the buttocks, back and sometimes other parts of the body in infants.(Option B)
  • Pustular melanosis, which is more common among infants, is a transient benign, self-limited dermatosis of unknown etiology that is characterized by 3 types of lesions:
    1. Evanescent superficial pustules,
    2. Ruptured pustules with a collarette of fine scale, at times with a central hyperpigmented macule, and
    3. Hyperpigmented macules.(Option C)
  • Infantile Acropustulosis-The lesions are initially discrete erythematous papules that become vesiculopustular within 24 hr and subsequently crust before healing. They are intensely pruritic. Preferred sites are the palms of the hands and the soles and sides of the feet, where the lesions may be extensive.(Option D)

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 3454

questions.text: All of the following can be the clinical possibilities in a child with the following, except?
questions.solution:
The image is showing presence of pitting type of pedal edema in the child. Thiamine deficiency, producing the so-called 'Dry Beri-Beri' can have CCF-like symptoms and have pedal edema. Likewise, maladaptive PEM, also known as Kwashiorkor, has bilateral pitting edema. Hypoalbuminemia can also produce pitting edema, due to low oncotic pressure. However, Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic congenital heart disease and has minimal to no risk of CCF and thus pedal edema is not likely to be seen in this patient.

Reference: Nelson Pediatric symptom-based diagnosis, Pg. 315

questions.text: A 5 year old child with multiple hyperpigmented brown macules on the body was also found to have similar findings in axillary region. His IQ was normal but brain MRI revealed basal ganglia hyperintensities on T2-weighed image, without any mass effect, as shown below. Repeat MRI done in the child 2 years later showed disappearance of these lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• A child with multiple hyperpigmented brown macules suggests presence of Café-au-lait macules.
  • Similar hyperpigmented lesions in axilla suggests Axillary Freckling.
  • Likely diagnosis is NF-1
  • Now, MRI shows hyperintensities on T2 in basal ganglia which disappeared after some years.
  • This suggests the finding of UBO- Unidentified bright objects. These Are Abnormal hyperintense signals on T2in optic tract, globus pallidus, brain stem, cerebellum .
  • As age increases → UBOs Reduce and Disappear
  • Significance is not clear, but is a highly interesting finding seen in children with NF-1

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 1991

questions.text: Which among the following pediatric condition is associated with mutations in ITPKC gene as well as anti-endothelial cell antibodies positivity?
questions.solution:
The likely condition is Kawasaki Disease:

  • Exact cause is unknown. Considered to be a T-cell mediated disease
  • More common in Japanese population
  • Young children more affected, with peak age of 18-24 months
  • Males are more commonly affected than females
  • Anti-Endothelial cell antibodies are positive in many patients, although they are not implicated directly in the disease pathogenesis
  • Genes implicated in Kawasaki disease include ITPKC, CASP-3
  • HSP has IgA deposited in small vessel walls.(Option B)
  • sJIA is characterized by dysregulation of the innate immune system with a lack of autoreactive T-cells and autoantibodies. It therefore may be more accurately classified as an autoinflammatory disorder.(Option C)
  • A hallmark of SLE is the generation of autoantibodies directed against self-antigens, particularly nucleic acids. (Option D)

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1310

choices.text: IgG Anti EMA + Total Serum IgA

questions.text: A child suspected to have Celiac disease is to be evaluated. Which of the following will be the 1st line screening investigations you will advise in the child, based upon the latest guidelines?
questions.solution:
As per the latest ESPGHAN guidelines, as well as Nelson, in any suspected Celiac disease patient, IgA Anti-TTG is the antibody screening test of choice. However, owing to the high association with Selective IgA deficiency, the current guidelines suggest doing BOTH IgA Anti-TTG as well as Total Serum IgA as the initial screening test of choice. Further decision is based upon test results and titres of antibodies.


Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1991

questions.text: A 3 year old child presented with high chills with fever, hepatosplenomegaly and a lesion as shown in the picture. Peripheral blood showed thrombocytopenia and transaminitis. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture plus image showing single, black eschar is suggestive of Rickettsial infection like Scrub Typhus. The drug of choice in patients, even below 8 yr age is Doxycycline.

  • IP: 10-12 days
  • High fever with chills, headache: Maculopapular rash on Day 4-5 in <50% cases, Hepatomegaly in 2/3rd, Splenomegaly in 1/3rdpatients
  • GIT Symptoms in 40%, LAP in 23-93% cases
  • Hallmark: A Single Painless ESCHAR
  • In untreated cases, fever disappears in the 3rdweek
  • HLH Syndrome may occur
  • Leukocytosis, Thrombocytopenia and Transaminitis are common
  • Weil-Felix test may be positive but has availability issues

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1627

questions.text: A child has just started to move on all 4 limbs as shown below. When does the following movement begin in a child?
questions.solution:
The child being shown in the image is doing crawling, which begins at 8-9 months. In crawling, abdomen is touching the ground. Creeping, which involves abdomen lifted off the ground, comes about 1 month later at 9-10 months.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 135

questions.text: Which among the following is effective in systemic onset JIA (SoJIA)?
questions.solution:
Systemic onset JIE, also called SoJIA requires Short course of Oral Corticosteroids, followed by Anakinra/Tocilizumab/Cankinumab.

  • SoJIA shows poor response to NSAIDs and Anti-TNF Alpha Drugs.
  • Rituximab has no role in its management

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1262

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis in India?
questions.solution:
Most common causes of neonatal sepsis- As per latest data

  • Most common cause overall and worldwide: Group B Streptococci> E coli> Klebsiella
  • In India: Klebsiella> Staphylococcus aureus> E coli
  • Fungal cause: Candida albicans> Candida parapsilosis

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 527

questions.text: Which among the following is the procedure of choice in aspirated foreign bodies in lower airway in children?
questions.solution:
Rigid bronchoscopy is both diagnostic and therapeutic procedure in children who aspirate foreign body into the lower airway in children. Flexible fibreoptic bronchoscopy can not be used to remove stuck FB.

  • Rigid bronchoscopy is preferred over flexible one.(Option A)
  • Heimlich is used for laryngeal foreign body.(Option C)
  • Wire guided aspiration is not done.(Option D)

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 941

questions.text: A child has recently been diagnosed with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Which among the following is the most likely clinical association?
questions.solution:
Hyperbilirubinemia is the most common clinical association of pyloric stenosis, also known as icteropyloric syndrome. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is more common than conjugated and usually resolves with surgical correction of the pyloric stenosis. It may be associated with a decreased level of glucuronyl transferase as seen in approximately 5% of affected infants; mutations in the bilirubin uridine diphosphate glucuronosyltransferase gene (UGT1A1) have also been implicated.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1946

questions.text: Fats should normally contribute to what % of calories in a normal child?
questions.solution:
Fats are major source of energy in diet. In normally growing children, about 25-30% of energy intake should be derived from fat which includes 10-15% invisible fat. However, in malnourished children, up to 45% of calories can be safely provided from fat.

Reference: Nutrition & child development, KE Elizabeth, 5th ed., Pg. 136

questions.text: A child with genetically proven Trisomy 21, comes to you for routine follow up. While counselling the parents, you must mention that the child is at increased risk of which of the following tumors, compared to general population?
questions.solution:
Persons with Down syndrome have fewer-than-expected deaths caused by solid tumours and ischemic heart disease. There is decreased risk of solid tumours in all age-groups with Down syndrome, including neuroblastomas and nephroblastomas in children and epithelial tumours in adults.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 660

questions.text: Anticipation phenomenon occurs in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Anticipation is a pattern of inheritance in which symptoms became manifest at earlier ages and with increasing severity as traits are passed to subsequent generations. The genetic defect in myotonic muscular dystrophy is on chromosome 19 at the 19q13 locus. It consists of an expansion of the DM gene that encodes a serine- threonine kinase (DMPK), with numerous repeats of the CTG codon. Myotonic dystrophy often exhibits a pattern of anticipation in which each successive generation has a tendency to be more severely involved than the previous generation.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 651

questions.text: Molecular therapy using CD34+ hematopoietic stem cells transduced with lentiviral vector has recently been approved for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Betibeglogene autotemcel, also called Beti-Cel or Zynteglo, is an autologous gene therapy that adds functional copies of the β-globin gene (βA-T87Q-globin) to hematopoietic stem cells in order to treat β-thalassemia. Patients treated with betibeglogene autotemcel are given an infusion of their own hematopoietic stem cells, previously enriched for CD34+ and transduced ex vivo with BB305 LVV, a self-inactivating lentiviral vector (LVV). Approved by EU in May, 2019 and FDA in August, 2022.

Reference: Betibeglogene Autotemcel Gene Therapy for Non-β0/β0 Genotype β-Thalassemia, New England Journal of Medicine, Feb'22

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of bronchiolitis obliterans in children?
questions.solution:
Bronchiolitis obliterans (BO) is an uncommon form of obstructive lung disease that occurs as a result of a severe insult to the small airways and ultimately leads to fibrosis and obliteration of the bronchioles. Epidemiology studies suggest that BO occurs frequently in children of Asian and South American descent. In children, the leading cause of BO is infectious, with adenovirus being the most common offending agent. BO also occurs in patients with lung or bone marrow transplants (BMTs) and in those with autoimmune disorders. Other causes include toxic inhalation injury or aspiration, hypersensitivity pneumonitis, drug toxicity, and Stevens-Johnson syndrome, SJS.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 2227

questions.text: Use of aspirin in a child is associated with which among the following disorders?
questions.solution:
According to Nelson 21st Ed, 'Reye's syndrome is a secondary mitochondrial hepatopathy, which is often precipitated in a genetically susceptible person by the interaction of a viral infection (influenza, varicella) and salicylate and/or antiemetic use.' Other options mentioned have no association with aspirin usage.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 2126

questions.text: In a child suspected to be having a genetic cause of hyperbilirubinemia, genetic study shows mutation in ABCC2 gene. Which of the following disease shows such mutation?
questions.solution:
Dubin-Johnson syndrome is an autosomal recessive inherited defect in hepatocyte secretion of bilirubin glucuronide. The defect in hepatic excretory function is not limited to conjugated bilirubin excretion but also involves several organic anions normally excreted from the liver cell into bile. Disease results from absent function of multiple drug-resistant protein 2 (MRP2, encoded by the gene ABCC2 ), an adenosine triphosphate-dependent canalicular transporter.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 2103

questions.text: Most common indication of liver transplantation in children is?
questions.solution:
Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplantation in children, followed by metabolic disorders.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 2136

questions.text: Brentuximab vedotin is useful in the management of which malignancy?
questions.solution:
Brentuximab vedotin is an antibody- drug conjugate approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to treat HL. It combines the chimeric anti-CD30 antibody brentuximab linked to the antimitotic agent monomethyl auristatin E. This agent shows impressive efficacy as single-agent therapy in refractory HL and is currently being tested as part of upfront therapy combined with chemotherapy in patients with newly diagnosed disease.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 2659

questions.text: Trilateral retinoblastoma comprises bilateral retinoblastomas plus____?
questions.solution:
Associated tumours in a patient with RB include

  • Osteosarcoma
  • Soft tissue sarcomas
  • Malignant melanomas
  • In a patient with existing RB, the next MC malignancy to look for→Osteosarcoma
  • In 5% cases, B/L RB is associated with a pinealoblastoma→ Called as Trilateral Retinoblastoma. It usually carries a very poor prognosis.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 2697

choices.text: Head and neck squamous cell cancers

questions.text: A 5-year-old child being evaluated for pancytopenia was found to have abnormality as shown in the picture. Chromosomal breakage studies are indicative of increased fragility of chromatids. HSCT is planned but the parents are counselled about the potential for increased morbidity in 3rd decade due to elevated risk of a specific complication. What is that complication most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Pancytopenia with thumb/radial abnormalities and increased chromosomal fragility points to a diagnosis of Fanconi Anemia.

  • Head and neck cancer risk is increased 4.4-fold and is accelerated by approximately 15 yr compared to non-transplanted patients.
  • These cancers are of squamous cell type and tend to be associated with HPV infection.
  • The cumulative incidence of malignancy 20 yr after transplant is 35-40% and is the major cause of morbidity and mortality in later life.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 2568

questions.text: Which of the following is used to monitor response to therapy in a patient of severe congenital CMV, who is being treated with ganciclovir?
questions.solution:
Fast detection methods for CMV viremia include: the antigenemia assay for detecting PP65 antigen in polymorphonuclear leukocytes from peripheral blood, polymerase chain reaction (PCR), nucleic acid sequence-based amplification (NASBA), and molecular methods such as branched-DNA signal amplification assay (b-DNA) and hybrid capture. Quantitative PP65 antigen assay performed on blood is a good test for diagnosing CMV disease and monitoring response to antiviral therapy in a high sero-endemic populations.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1721

questions.text: A child is able to repeat a sentence of 6 syllables at what age?
questions.solution:
Milestones


Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 143

questions.text: Not a component of VACTERL syndrome?
questions.solution:
VACTERL syndrome

  • V: Vertebral anomalies
  • A: Anal atresia
  • C: Cardiac defects
  • T: Tracheoesophageal fistula
  • E: Esophageal atresia
  • R: Renal and Radial anomalies
  • L: Limb defects

Reference: Cloherty and stark's manual of Neonatal care, SA ed., Pg. 541

questions.text: A 6-week old infant presents with failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly and adrenal insufficiency. USG abdomen showed bilateral adrenal calcification. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Wolman disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the gene encoding human lysosomal acid lipase on chromosome 10q 23.2-23.3. Cholesteryl esters accumulate in lysosomes in most organ systems, leading to organ failure. Infants during the 1st or 2nd mo of life have hepatosplenomegaly, steatorrhea, abdominal distention and failure to thrive. Adrenal insufficiency and bilateral adrenal calcification are present and death usually occurs in the 1st yr of life.

  • Wilms tumor mostly is an incidental finding of painless abdominal mass or found during routine abdominal examination. Hypertension is the next most common finding in WT.(Option A)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy usually presents in preschoolers as hyperactive behavior often mistaken as ADHD in a previously normal child.(Option B)
  • CAH can present with these features but presence of adrenal calcification favors Wolman disease.(Option C)

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 761

questions.text: Dopamine Hypothesis has been proposed for which neurobehavioural disorder in children?
questions.solution:
Functional MRI data suggest deficits in dispersed functional networks for selective and sustained attention in ADHD that include the striatum, prefrontal regions, parietal lobe, and temporal lobe. The prefrontal cortex and basal ganglia are rich in dopamine receptors. This knowledge, plus data about the dopaminergic mechanisms of action of medication treatment for ADHD, has led to the dopamine hypothesis, which postulates that disturbances in the dopamine system may be related to the onset of ADHD. Fluorodopa positron emission tomography (PET) scans also support the dopamine hypothesis through the identification of low levels of dopamine activity in adults with ADHD.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 264

questions.text: Most common pediatric cardiac tumours and the underlying syndrome?
questions.solution:
Rhabdomyomas are the most common pediatric cardiac tumours and are associated with tuberous sclerosis in 70-95% of cases.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 3144

questions.text: An infant has just been diagnosed as a case of d-TGA. What shall be the procedure of choice in this child for correction?
questions.solution:
The arterial switch(Jatene) procedure is the surgical treatment of choice for neonates with d-TGA and an intact ventricular septum and is usually performed within the first 2 weeks of life.

  • Rashkind procedure is atrial septostomy, used in TGA. It is a rescue surgery till corrective Jatene's procedure is carried out.(Option A)
  • Glenns surgery and Fontan surgery are for Hypoplastic left heart syndrome.(Option B, C)

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 2434

questions.text: Parents of a 1-year-old child comes with HPLC report suggestive of high HbS levels. Which of the following change is expected in amino acid position in this child's hemoglobin structure?
questions.solution:
Sickle cell hemoglobinopathy occurs due to mutation of beta-globin gene situated on short arm of chromosome 11, where adenine is replaced by thymine in base of DNA coding for the amino acid in the sixth position in beta-globin chain. This leads to an amino acid change in beta chain of Hb molecule, from glutamic acid to valine.The result is profound change in the molecular stability and solubility of Hb 'S'.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 2541

questions.text: Cryoprecipitate will control bleeding due to deficiency of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate contains fibrinogen, factor VIII, factor XIII, Von Willibrand factor and fibronectin. Hence, it is useful in conditions with hypofibrinogenemia, factor VIII and XIII deficiency and vWF deficiency.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg no. 2586

questions.text: A child presents with history of high-grade fever for 4 days. A non-itchy rash develops on trunk on the day after the fever subsides and then spreads to the face. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Non-itchy rash appearing on trunk after onset of fever is a typical presentation seen with Roseola infantum, caused by HHV-6 virus.

  • Measles and rubella, rashes appear first on face and spreads downwards.(Option B & C)
  • Varicella lesions are fluid filled.(Option D)

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1742

questions.text: Most common type of trachea-esophageal fistula, TEF in neonates is?
questions.solution:
Types of TEF


Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1930

questions.text: Most common cause of hand foot and mouth disease?
questions.solution:
Hand-foot-and-mouth disease

  • MC Cause: Coxsackievirus A16
  • Other causes: Enterovirus 71 (2ndMC cause); coxsackie A viruses 5, 6, 7, 9, and 10; coxsackie B viruses 2 and 5; and some echoviruses

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1692

questions.text: Petechiae on junction of soft and hard palate are seen in?
questions.solution:
Symptomatic EBV infections in older children and adults are characterized by insidious onset with symptoms such as malaise, fatigue, fever, headache, nausea, sore throat, abdominal pain and myalgia. Examination shows pharyngeal inflammation with exudates and petechiae at the junction of soft and hard palate, generalized lymphadenopathy (cervical, less often axillary and inguinal), mild splenomegaly (50%) and hepatomegaly (10%). Maculopapular rashes are seen in 3-15% and in 30% of those who have received ampicillin or amoxicillin.

  • Roseola infantum has ulcers at uvulopalatoglossal region.(Nagayama spots)(Option A)
  • Measles have Koplik spots opposite to molars.(Option B)
  • Enteric fever has less common oral findings.(Option C)

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1715

questions.text: Retinopathy of prematurity is commonly predisposed by?
questions.solution:
As per Nelson 21st Ed, the most important factor involved in retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is low gestational age, followed by low birth weight. Hyperoxia, co-morbidities and mechanical ventilation are other co-factors, but less important than prematurity alone.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 3377

questions.text: Most common cause of death in childhood measles?
questions.solution:
Pneumonia is MCC of death in measles, whereas Acute otitis media is MC complication of measles. Diarrhea causes post measles mortality and SSPE is a rare late complication of measles.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1673

questions.text: Not involved in anterior fontanelle formation?
questions.solution:
Look at the image showing the neonatal skull.


Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 869

questions.text: In pediatric emergencies, when intravenous access is not viable, which of the following sites are preferred for obtaining intraosseous access?
questions.solution:
Intraosseous (IO) access in pediatric resuscitation

  • IO cannulation is recommended for patients for whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable, even in older children, irrespective of age.
  • Intraosseous (IO) needles (for intramedullary venous plexus access) are special rigid, large-bore needles that resemble those used for bone marrow aspiration.
  • If venous access is not available within 1 min in a child with cardiopulmonary arrest, an IO needle should be placed in the anterior proximal tibia (with care taken to avoid traversing the epiphyseal plate). The needle should penetrate the anterior layer of compact bone, and its tip advanced into the spongy interior of the bone
  • Any medications, blood products, and fluids may be administered through the IO route, including all medications required for emergency resuscitation.
  • Complications are uncommon, but may include osteomyelitis with prolonged infusions and tibial fracture

Reference: Pediatric Advanced Life Support Guidelines, AAP, 2021

questions.text: Which heart disease is most commonly associated with congenital rubella infection?
questions.solution:
In congenital rubella syndrome, MC congenital heart disease is PDA, followed by PA Stenosis, then Pulmonary Valvular Stenosis and eventually, septal defects like ASD and VSD.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 21st ed., Pg. 1679
